author: potuz
content: Hello, do we have data on how many hops do blocks pass to get to a typical node? or what's the max number of them? or p95?

author: popef
content: It's very hard to measure that. What we usually do when we estimate the number of hops is log_D (N) where N is number of nodes and D is the degree (which is 5 hops with N=10,000 and D=8)

author: popef
content: Another way to do that is to ask graph theorists what is the expected diameter of a graph with each node having degree D, but the real world graph may not look like that.

author: potuz
content: Yeah I get that it's tough to measure but perhaps we can set some sentry nodes to ping at different places to try to they this? If we're at 5 hops more or less this is pretty encouraging

author: popef
content:
> we can set some sentry nodes to ping at different places to try to they this
I don't see how this helps.

author: potuz
content: yeah, neither do I unless we modify clients to keep track of extra data off-protocol per hop. Attackers can screw up the meassurement, but there's no incentive on doing so

author: potuz
content: I'm only interested in a rough estimate, doesn't need to be precise

author: potuz
content: but if it were true that it's of the order of 5-10 that's great

We discussed about adding this many times in the past, the only issue is when you know you connect to the original publisher, it kind of kills anonymity.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: what if we added an optional "hop count" field to the block gossip messages that clients could increment like an inverse of the IP TTL field? it could of course be "attacked"  but like you said theres no incentive to do so.  I'm guessing we don't want to waste a byte with this though.

author: nishant0
content: The main opposition to having it was that it killed anonymity and allowed us to narrow down on the message originator

author: nishant0
content: It would have to be non-optional to be useful for the network
